title: How to Sand Fiberglass

steps.headline: Peel off any decals or stickers by heating them up.
steps.description: These decorations are common on boats and cars and will get in the way when you sand the fiberglass. These decals come off easily when they're heated. Use a heat gun on a low setting and peel any stickers off. If you don't have a heat gun, try heating the stickers with a blow dryer instead. Don't use a knife or scraper to remove the stickers because you could scratch the fiberglass.

steps.headline: Wipe off any adhesive residue with acetone.
steps.description: If your fiberglass piece ever had decals or stickers on it, there is probably adhesive residue left over on the surface. This prevents you from sanding properly in these areas. Pour some acetone onto a rag and scrub areas where stickers were attached to remove the residue. Acetone is available at hardware stores. Use safety precautions when using acetone. Keep any flames away from it because it’s flammable. Wear gloves to prevent acetone from getting on your skin and do not put your face near it. If any acetone gets on your skin, flush the area with running water for 5 minutes. If you ingest it or get any in your eyes, contact poison control immediately.

steps.headline: Wash the fiberglass with dish soap and water.
steps.description: Clean the fiberglass surface before you sand it. Make a soapy mixture of water and a few drops of dish soap. Stir the mixture so suds form. Then dip a sponge or rag in and scrub the fiberglass surface. If you use a sponge, don’t use the rough side. This could scratch the fiberglass. If you’re working with a small enough object, wash it in your sink or bathtub. If the object is larger than this, such as a tub or boat, wash it outside with a hose.

steps.headline: Rinse the fiberglass with clean water and let it air-dry.
steps.description: Spray the object down with a hose or run it under your faucet. Remove all suds and soap residue. Then wait for the fiberglass to air dry on its own before doing any sanding.

parts.name: Sanding and Repairing the Fiberglass Surface

steps.headline: Put a dust mask, goggles, and gloves on before you start sanding.
steps.description: Fiberglass strands can irritate your skin, eyes, and throat. Sanding the fiberglass sends these particles into the air. Protect yourself with a dust mask that covers your mouth and nose. Prevent skin and eye irritations with gloves and goggles. If you're using a power sander, wear long sleeves and pants as well. Power sanders send even more dust and residue into the air.

steps.headline: Sand small pieces of fiberglass by hand with medium-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: The point of sanding fiberglass is to remove the outer gloss finish so paint can adhere properly. Use 120- to 180-grit sandpaper or a sanding block and move it back and forth over the surface. Only sand until the glossy finish starts coming off and the surface is no longer shiny. Sand the whole surface of the fiberglass. If you miss any spots, your paint will look uneven.

steps.headline: Use a power sander for large fiberglass pieces to speed up the process.
steps.description: Power sanders are only appropriate for big jobs like this that can't be done by hand. Load your sander with a medium-grit paper (from 120-180). Keep the sander moving constantly to prevent friction from building up in one spot. Stop sanding when the glossy layer comes off and the finish is no longer shiny. For smaller fiberglass pieces, a power sander creates too much friction.

steps.headline: Stop sanding if you see fibers coming up through the gloss.
steps.description: Only remove the top gloss layer and do not penetrate down to the fiberglass itself. If you see any strands or fibers coming up, you’ve hit the fiberglass. Stop sanding in that spot immediately. Use a lighter touch in other spots to prevent similar ruptures. Don’t worry if you exposed the fiberglass by sanding too hard. You can repair this easily.

steps.headline: Repair any breaks in the fiberglass by filling it with resin.
steps.description: If you’ve penetrated the glossy finish and hit the fiberglass, repair these gaps before you finish the job. Get fiberglass resin, hardener, and cloth matting from a hardware or auto repair store. Cut a piece of matting the size of the area you have to repair and put it over the damaged area. Then mix the resin and hardener together and brush it onto the matting. Sand this area again after the resin dries. Make sure you don’t break through the surface layer this time.

steps.headline: Wipe down the whole surface with mineral spirits to remove any dust.
steps.description: Sanding the fiberglass surface leaves behind residue and dust. Clean off the fiberglass by wetting a rag with some mineral spirits and wiping every area you sanded. You don’t have to scrub or wipe hard. The wet rag should pick up any reside easily. Mineral spirits are less abrasive than many solvents, but can still cause irritation. Avoid inhaling or splashing it into your eyes, and work in a well-ventilated area. If you get any on your hands, run them under a faucet for 5 minutes. After the fiberglass is completely cleaned off, you can proceed with painting it if that's your goal.
